thread.title: Chip Kelly explains Eagles' sudden emergence on defense
thread.title_full: Chip Kelly explains Eagles' sudden emergence on defense

author: Matt Lombardo | For NJ Advance Media
title: Chip Kelly explains Eagles' sudden emergence on defense
text:
Comments 
PHILADELPHIA -- After six games, it seems as though the Eagles oddly enough, have become a team led by a dominant defense that is winning games in spite of an inconsistent offense. 
Few expected that to be the hallmark of a .500 Eagles team perched atop the NFC East with Chip Kelly at the helm and an offense that was dramatically remade over during a frenetic offseason. 
MORE : Kelly says Eagles still have complete confidence in Bradford 
Yet, that is how the Eagles have operated over the past two games while holding the Giants to 247 total yards and seven points in Week 6 and the New Orleans Saints to 388 yards and 17 points in Week 5, with a majority of that production coming well after the outcome had been decided. 
REPORT CARD: Sam Bradford struggles, Eagles win despite poor QB play 
On Tuesday Kelly explained what has sparked the defense's sudden streak of dominance. 
"I think it's improved personnel but there's also a comfort level with the players and the system," Kelly said Tuesday during his day-after press conference at the NovaCare Complex. "Brandon [Graham] is here for three years. Connor [Barwin] is here for three years, that front-seven with the exception of Jordan Hicks has been here for awhile. 
"The fact that you have a player like Malcolm [Jenkins] who has kind of helped keep the back-end together and now Walter [Thurmond], Byron Maxwell and E.J. Biggers have started to all form a group back there in the secondary has also really helped. 
"The one thing that Billy [Davis] has benefited from is that continuity that we have up front is we've had the same defensive line and those outside linebackers have played a ton of snaps for us. Really just the only addition at inside linebacker is Jordan Hicks who has exceeded some people's expectations, not ours, in terms of what he can handle as a rookie ... When you have some continuity from that standpoint, those guys understand the system to the point where you can make tweaks and you can make adjustments when the offense presents something. When the coaches are talking about adjustments, the players are finishing their sentences." 
DEMARCO MURRAY: Has Eagles' running back put slow start behind him? 
In early season losses to the Atlanta Falcons, Dallas Cowboys and Washington Redskins, the lack of in-game adjustments was one of the loudest -- and most accurate -- criticisms both of Kelly, Davis and the rest of the coaching staff. However, it was a markedly different story in Monday's win over the Giants. 
After watching Eli Manning surgically move the Giants down the field on an eight-play, 80-yard scoring drive, the defense tightened. Those were the only seven points the Giants could muster all evening and DeMeco Ryans forced two turnovers and Carroll's interception seemed to inject life into the defense in the second quarter. 
This defense is far from a finished product, but there is a certain swagger present with the group that had been missing early on. 
"We believe we're the best team in the division," Byron Maxwell told NJ Advance Media following the game on Monday night. "But, every week you have to go out there and prove it. So, we feel that way. We know this isn't our Super Bowl. We have to keep going." 
Next up is a clash with Cam Newton and the undefeated Carolina Panthers on Sunday night in Charlotte. If the past two games are any indication, it appears the Eagles' defense is up for the challenge of slowing one of the league's most dynamic quarterbacks, once again on a national stage.
